page.title: 01Canterbury and Planning
page.content: Canterbury is a religious centre, a market town, a centre for learning, a place to live and work, a tourist centre and the shopping and service centre for East Kent. The broad{planning}strategy for Canterbury is defined in the local plan. This plan recognises the special character of the built{environment,} but also acknowledges the city's many and diverse functions. The plan allows for a small population increase up to 1991. To meet this 2800{dwellings}are planned for within the present urban area. To provide for jobs, the plan sees growth in retail, tourism, recreation, education and health services. Canterbury is to be maintained as a sub-regional{shopping}centre, with continual expansion of non-food / company shops.
